content.text: The input() function allows your program to receive information typed by the user. It is one of the first steps toward creating truly interactive programs.

items: Displays a message (if you provide one).
Waits for the user to type something.
Returns what was typed as a text string (str).

content.text:
name = input("Enter your name: ")
print("Hello,", name)

Enter your name: Linus
Hello, Linus

content.code:
name = input("Enter your name: ")
print("Hello,", name)

content.text:
üìå Note:
Everything that input() returns is text, even if the user types a number.
If you need to work with numbers, you must convert the text that comes from input().

age = input("How old are you?")
age = int(age)    # necessary conversion
print("Next year you will be", age + 1)

How old are you? 55
Next year you will be 56

content.code:
age = input("How old are you?")
age = int(age)
print("Next year you will be", age + 1)

double = number * 2
print("The double is:", double)
